content:
• Tuesday, August 27, 2013

  • Asian stocks slide amid geopolitical tensions

    • The possibility of an imminent U.S. military strike on Syria has global equities reeling on the heels of Wall Street's worst day since June.
    • The Nikkei trades down nearly 2% in Tokyo in a broad-based sell-off.
    • Across the region: ASX -1%, Kospi -0.5%, Shanghai Composite -0.8%, Hang Seng -1.6%
     
     
     
     
    | 9:35 PM | 1 Comment
  • AVAV

    AeroVironment guidance strong, but investors sell on news

    • AeroVironment (NASDAQ:AVAV) expects FY14 (ends April '14) revenue of $230M-$250M and EPS of $0.35-$0.50, generally favorable to a consensus of $233.3M and $0.40.
    • Backlog rose 29% Q/Q in FQ1 to $76.9M after falling 16% in FQ4. Also, the company notes orders for its Raven UAVs have arrived in FQ2
    • UAV division sales -28% Y/Y to $35.2M (were -56% in FQ4). EV charging system division sales -10% to $8.9M (-12% in FQ4).
    • R&D spend -9% Y/Y to $7.2M, SG&A -8% to $12.5M.
    • Shares -3.5% AH after rallying this summer on hopes Engaged Capital will bring about some changes.
    • FQ1 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 6:38 PM

  • After-hours top gainers / Losers

    • After-hours top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: ARAY +9.84%. AVGO +6%. TWI +6%. BFR +3.85%. NBG +2.70%.
    • After-hours top losers: QIHU  -4.05%. AVAV -3.47%. FSL -2.93%. NQ -2.69%. DAR -2.42%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:41 PM
  • PNG

    PAA Natural Gas Storage gets buyout offer from Plains All American

    • PAA Natural Gas Storage (NYSE:PNG) +6.7% AH after receiving a buyout proposal from Plains All American Pipeline (NYSE:PAA) for all outstanding publicly held common units through a unit-for-unit exchange.
    • The proposed consideration represents a value of $22.74/unit based on the trailing 10-day average closing price of PAA's common units through Aug. 26.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:38 PM | 1 Comment
  • WTSL

    Wet Seal soars after Q2 results

    • Wet Seal (NASDAQ:WTSL) soars 9% AH, adding to a late rally which propelled the shares 3.3% higher into the close.
    • Net sales for Q2 rise 1% Y/Y.
    • Comps growth comes in at 3.7%, far better than the numbers put up by some teen retailers earlier in the month.
    • Gross margin expands by 680 bps due to "reduced markdown levels" — who knew that was possible in today's retail environment?
    • "As we look at the second half of the year, were encouraged by how the business is positioned from both a financial and operational perspective," management says.
    • Q3 outlook: Net loss of $0.02-0.03/ share on revenue of $135-138M. Comps growth in the mid-single digits. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:21 PM
  • BVN

    Gold prices rise but miners plunge

    • Gold (GLD +0.9%) benefited from today's risk-off investment climate but gold stocks are stocks first and gold plays second (if that), as the miners (GDX -4.2%) finished among the day's worst performers; they also tend to get hit hard by rising oil prices.
    • BVN -6.8%, NGD -6.1%, CDE -5.7%, AUQ -5.6%, IAG -5.3%, SLW -4.9%, KGC -4.4%, AUY -4.4%, GG -4.3%, RGLD -4.2%, NEM -3.5%, ABX -3.4%, AU -3.1%, GFI -2.5%, HMY -2%.
    • ETFs: GDXJ, GLDX, PSAU, NUGT, DUST, GGGG, RING, SIL, SLVP, SILJ.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:15 PM
  • QIHU

    Qihoo announces $550M convertible debt offering, shares -3.7% AH

    • Qihoo (NYSE:QIHU) is taking advantage of its giant 2013 run-up to offer $550M worth of convertible senior notes due Sep. 2018. (PR)
    • A $50M overallotment option exists. The notes can be redeemed "under certain circumstances on or after September 20, 2016."
    • Qihoo had $379M in cash/investments on its balance sheet at the end of Q2, and no debt. Is the company looking to use the offering to help finance a deal for Sohu's Sogou unit?
     
     
     
     
    | 4:31 PM | 4 Comments
  • AVGO

    Avago guidance strong, "very strong" wireless product ramps expected

    • Avago (NASDAQ:AVGO) expects FQ4 revenue to rise 12%-15% Q/Q. That implies a range of $721M-$741M, well above a $697M consensus.
    • The FQ3 beat was fueled by strong data center and industrial chip demand, which offset weaker-than-expected wireless sales (high-end smartphone softness and declining Apple orders ahead of an iPhone refresh are likely factors). Optical component vendor Finisar has also reported seeing strong data center-related sales.
    • Avago expects "very strong product ramps in wireless" (read: new iPhones), together with continued wireline strength, to lift FQ4 sales. That could be a positive for Apple-dependent Cirrus Logic (NASDAQ:CRUS).
    • Though weaker-than-expected Avago's wireless chip sales (45% of total) rose 3% Q/Q and 20% Y/Y in FQ3. Demand for 4G RF components featuring Avago's FBAR filters (previous) has been growing quickly. Wired infrastructure sales (31% of total) jumped 32% Q/Q and 17% Y/Y. Industrial sales (24% of total) rose 18% Q/Q and fell 20% Y/Y.
    • Gross margin was 50.9%, -30 bps Q/Q and Y/Y.
    • Shares +6.7% AH. CC at 5PM ET. FQ3 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:25 PM
  • AVGO

    Avago Technology beats by $0.08, beats on revenues

    • Avago Technology (NASDAQ:AVGO): FQ3 EPS of $0.74 beats by $0.08.
    • Revenue of $644M (+6% Y/Y) beats by $21.22M. Shares +5.6% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:10 PM | 1 Comment
  • WTSL

    Wet Seal EPS in-line, misse on revenue

    • Wet Seal (NASDAQ:WTSL): Q2 EPS of $0.01 in-line.
    • Revenue of $137.2M misses by $1.13M. Shares -3.49% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:08 PM
  • TIVO

    TiVo Adj. Net Income of -$13.05M

    • TiVo (NASDAQ:TIVO): Q2 Adj. Net Income of -$13.05M.
    • Revenue of $100.09M beats by $26.47M. Shares +2.5% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:08 PM
  • ETR

    Entergy's reactor shutdown is latest victim of U.S. shale boom

    • Entergy's (ETR -0.8%) closing of its Vermont Yankee nuclear reactor is the latest evidence of the financial pressures confronting the U.S. nuclear industry caused by the shale gas boom.
    • ETR’s news follows Duke Energy’s (NYSE:DUK) retirement of the Crystal River plant in Florida, Dominion’s (NYSE:D) closure of the Kewaunee plant in Wisconsin, and Edison's (NYSE:EIX) retirement of both units at the San Onofre plant in California, as utilities decide that investing in older reactors is no longer commercially viable.
    • The head of the Nuclear Energy Institute says failure to reform power markets to support nuclear power would “jeopardize reliable electricity supplies."
    • ETFs:Â URA -3.4%, NLR -1.4%, NUCL -0.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM
  • GOLD

    Goodhaven: Barrick Gold intriguing as "an anti-Congress, anti-Fed hedge"

    • Goodhaven Fund managers Larry Pitkowsky and Keith Trauner, having once described investing in Barrick Gold (ABX -2.6%) as akin to running toward a fire, seem to be taking a liking to the stock as "an anti-Congress, anti-Fed hedge... hated by the world and yet which could multiply in value under certain circumstances."
    • The managers like the "dramatic change in the marching orders" with new CEO Jamie Sokalsky, who they say is focused on returns and not just size; "many of Barrick’s missteps in the last couple of years are on their way to being corrected."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:39 PM | 2 Comments
  • AAXN

    Taser rallies again, extends winning streak

    • Still flying under the radar are shares of Taser (TASR +1.9%) which, for those who haven't been following the August rally, have risen for 11 straight sessions.
    • Behind the big move — which has been good for around 36% since August 12 — is optimism surrounding the company's AXON on-officer cameras.
    • In an article published Monday, SA contributor Chris Katje says the company should comfortably beat analysts' Q3 estimates of $0.08/ share.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:21 PM
  • DWDP

    Dow Chemical confirms locations for expanding leading plastics brands

    • Dow Chemical (DOW -2.5%) confirms locations in Texas and Louisiana for expanding four of its top plastics brands, which it expects to drive strong revenue growth and generate ~$2.5B in EBITDA once fully operational.
    • Dow says the expansions will allow it to further leverage its cost-advantaged position and R&D expertise to deliver leading edge technology in some of its most strategic markets.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:56 PM | 1 Comment
  • MOV

    Movado rally has room to run: Barron's

    • Shares of Movado (MOV +8.2%) "still have room to rise," despite today's sharp post-earnings rally, Barron's says, citing the company's four-year plan to boost sales and profit growth.
    • MOV "has shifted its focus to its more-profitable wholesale business [and] is also improving profitability by offering new products and expanding into China," Johanna Bennett writes.
    • Quoted in the article is Stephens' analyst Rick Patel who calls the company a "standout."
    • Also: Sidoti raises PT to $53 from $49.
    • Earlier this month: Brean starts MOV at Buy.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:55 PM
  • UBNT

    Ubiquiti higher after Chinese counterfeiter sentenced

    • Kenny Kai Deng, accused by Ubiquiti (UBNT +3.2%) of counterfeiting its hardware, has been sentenced by a Shenzhen, China court to 5 years in jail and a RMB1M ($163K) fine. (PR)
    • Ubiquiti also notes a Dubai court recently froze over $2M in assets held by Asim Sajwani, a former distributor who worked with Deng.
    • Counterfeit goods took a toll on Ubiquiti's 2012 sales. Last year, the company obtained a restraining order against a Florida-based distributor accused of shipping counterfeit goods, and also scored legal wins against alleged counterfeiters in South America.
    • Shares have made new 52-week highs, and are up 179% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:42 PM | 2 Comments
  • AVAV

    Engaged Capital sends a letter to AeroVironment's Board

    • Engaged Capital says it's sent a letter to Aerovironment's (AVAV -1.9%) Board of Directors, expressing its disappointment in the board's failure to engage in constructive dialogue over the company's gross valuation discount, as well as its failure to seriously consider its independent director nominee and to provide proper governance and protections for the rights of its shareholders.
    • Engaged's Chief Investment Officer Glenn Welling notes, “AeroVironment’s failure to deliver meaningful shareholder returns over any relevant time period is a clear indication of a need for change."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:26 PM | 1 Comment
  • GOGL

    Knightsbridge Tankers surges 7% after Iberia upgrade

    • Knightsbridge Tankers (VLCCF +7.2%) is upgraded to Outperform from Sector Perform with a $10 price target at Iberia Capital, which believes the bulk carrier market is still 20%-30% oversupplied.
    • Strong scrappings (5%-6% of fleet) and robust demand growth (5%-8%) set the stage for better supply/demand metrics exiting 2014, which in turn leads to higher rates, the firm says.
    • VLCCF and shares of other bulk carriers could move 6-9 months ahead of a turn in fundamentals, the firm says.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:25 PM
  • NES

    Nuverra extends losses despite defense by Jefferies analyst

    • Nuverra Environmental (NES -6.6%) extends yesterday's losses sparked by a negative post on Seeking Alpha, which said "a liquidity crisis is looming" and shares could fall 80% over the next year.
    • Jefferies analyst Scott Graham is out defending NES, disputing claims that the company has a high probability of bankruptcy and saying the article ignores data on financial ratios "as seen by the banks."
    • Graham also points out that Dick Heckmann has not jumped ship and remains chairman with significant ownership.
    • The analyst is not positive on the stock, however, maintaining a Hold rating and cutting his price target to $2.75 from $3.25.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:12 PM | 4 Comments
  • ALGN

    Align Technology obtains the enforcement of permanent injunctions from a German court relating to patents

    • Align Technology (ALGN -1.5%) slips today, despite announcing late yesterday that a German court had ordered the enforcement of permanent injunctions against Ortho Caps GmbH and Rasteder KFO Spezial-Labor GmbH, ruling that the two companies had infringed on ALGN's patents related to its clear aligner therapy systems.
    • The lawsuits were filed separately by ALGN in December 2011.
    • The injunctions will require Ortho Caps and Rasteder KFO to account for all sales for their infringing products and pay any damages to ALGN resulting from their infringement.
    • The firms also were barred from making, offering to sell and selling in Germany any of the products the court found to infringe the patents.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:04 PM
  • STXS

    Stereotaxis gains on an upbeat SA article

    • Stereotaxis (STXS +8.9%) gains from an upbeat article in Seeking Alpha today.
    • The post, which featured an interview with life science investor DAFNA Capital, calls STXS the leading robotics company in the endovascular space, with the ability to become the 'Intuitive Surgical (NASDAQ:ISRG)' of catheter procedures.
    • DAFNA says ISRG has amongst the highest operating margins in the medical device industry and is an extremely profitable company.
    • STXS is also a business which can have extremely high profit margins, and when it reaches the appropriate scale to start focusing on profit, the investor thinks that shareholders will be very handsomely rewarded.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:30 PM | 2 Comments
  • PGNX

    Progenics adds to rally

    • Don't look now but Progenics Pharmaceuticals (PGNX +8.1%) is up 24% over the past three sessions.
    • The stock has now recouped its post-earnings losses.
    • In an article published Monday, SA contributor Michael Luo notes that Baker Bros. upped their stake last quarter.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:29 PM
  • XONE

    ExOne jumps following favorable CNBC mention

    • After trading lower this morning (like many other tech names), ExOne (XONE +2.9%) has shot higher on account of being mentioned on CNBC.
    • The gains come a day after shares rallied in sympathy with 3D Systems and Stratasys (they received bullish coverage launches), and ahead of a Friday lockup expiration. 7M+ shares will become available for sale; ExOne's float currently stands at 6.8M.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:28 PM | 3 Comments

  • Midday top 10 gainers / Losers

    • Midday top 10 gainers:Â  CPRX +46%. HITK +22%. GGS +15%. CCCR-OLD +14%. STXS +13%. AXU +12%. OTC:DSKX +11%. AKRX +10%. ABCD +10%.
    • Midday top 10 Losers: FFHL -35%. OTC:ACUR -21%. BCOM -18%. IGLD -14%. OTC:OBTEF -11%. SPEX -10%. LDK -10%. URZ -10%. AXX -10%. OTC:ECTE -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM | 2 Comments
  • NFEC

    NF Energy Saving lands a pumping station construction contract in Thailand

    • NF Energy Saving (NFEC +1.5%) gains after saying earlier that it's signed a valve contract with ST Energy Engineering Company in Thailand for a pumping station construction project.
    • NFEC will provide the project with 3 sets of 1500-to-2000 millimeter diameter valves and accessories with electric or hydraulic butterfly controls.
    • The order will be delivered in two shipments at the end of the Q3 and during Q1 of FY14.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:39 PM
  • NOK

    AT&T to sell Lumia 925; Deutsche calls Nokia a "value trap"

    • AT&T will begin selling the Lumia 925 (NOK -3.7%) on Sep. 13 for $100 with a 2-year contract. The Verge recently reported Nokia is planning to bring the high-end aluminum WP8 phone, currently offered in the U.S. only by T-Mobile USA, to additional U.S. carriers.
    • Meanwhile, Deutsche has joined ever-bearish Bernstein in issuing a downbeat note about Nokia, declaring shares a "value trap" on account of cash burn and overly optimistic valuation estimates.
    • Deutsche also argues NSN, now Nokia's biggest profit contributor, has seen its gross margin peak - the firm observes high-margin 4G capex in developed Asian markets is slowing - and stands to see revenue decline due to "limited" U.S./European growth prospects. The forecast comes in spite of ramping Chinese and European 4G capex, and the impact mobile data traffic growth is having on infrastructure needs.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:33 PM | 14 Comments
  • AMD

    AMD slumps following chip delay report

    • Digitimes reports the arrival of low-end desktop CPUs based on AMD's (AMD -4.3%) recently-launched (28nm) Kabini architecture has been pushed back to March '14 from 2H13. Moreover, the arrival of Beema, Kabini's successor (also 28nm), has been pushed back to 1H15 from 2H14.
    • The site also reports AMD's high-end Hawaii GPUs will launch at the end of September; that's in-line with recent reports. Hawaii is pivotal to AMD's efforts to take back high-end GPU share from Nvidia's (NVDA -1%) Kepler GPUs. Nvidia is expected to launch its next-gen Maxwell GPU line in Q1 2014, and might refresh its Kepler lineup later this year.
    • Digitimes reported last month the launch of AMD's Kaveri CPUs (based on the 28nm Steamroller architecture and aimed at mid-range/high-end PCs) could be delayed until Feb. '14. Kaveri's successor, Carrizo (based on the 28nm Excavator architecture), is due in 2015.
    • CPU delays serve to extend Intel's (INTC -1.1%) manufacturing process edge over AMD. Intel is in the midst of ramping production of its second-gen 22nm Haswell CPUs, and is expected to launch its 14nm Broadwell CPUs in 2H14. 22nm and (subsequently) 14nm Atom CPUs are also on tap.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:09 PM | 12 Comments
  • LLIT

    Dehaier Medical Systems slips on lower first half revenues Y/Y

    • Dehaier Medical Systems (DHRM -9.3%) takes a hit today after reporting its earnings during the first six months of 2013 dropped to $0.33 per share from $0.39 per share, below what it posted during the same period last year.
    • Six-month revenue declined by 19.26% year over year to $8.33M.
    • The company says its working capital stands at around $30M, which should be adequate to meet its anticipated cash needs and sustain current operations for at least 12 months.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:40 AM
  • RCM

    Accretive Health downgraded to Perform at Oppenheimer

    • Accretive Health (AH -4%) slips after being downgraded to Perform by Oppenheimer.
    • Price target information was not available.
    • Yesterday, the company announced a shift in its financial leadership, appointing Sean Orr as its new chief financial officer and treasurer, replacing its current CFO, John Staton.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:21 AM
  • NVIV

    InVivo plunges again as company updates scaffolding clinical plan

    • Shares of InVivo Therapeutics (NVIV -22.3%) plummet for the second time in three sessions.
    • NVIV said today that "based on the judgement of new management," the first patient for a clinical trial of the company's biopolymer scaffolding is now expected to be enrolled in Q1 2014. NVIV also said it expects enrollment to take at least 21 months.
    • In May, the company said it expected to "commence the study in mid-2013 and submit data to the FDA by the end of 2014."
    • There's also chatter from SA contributor Biotech Sage (whose article looks to have been the impetus behind Friday's plunge) that "all video and TV appearances of [former CEO] Reynolds were removed" from the company's IR page.
    • SA contributor and Zacks analyst Jason Napodano is skeptical of an Aegis note which purportedly defends the shares: "Wow, Aegis out with a note saying, 'NVIV news is only slight delay' ... I don't consider 5-6 years a 'slight delay.'"
    • On the bright side, SA contributor Nancy Zhang is out with a more bullish take on the shares.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:11 AM | 2 Comments
  • XEC

    Cimarex shares push higher after FBR upgrade

    • Cimarex Energy (XEC +2.6%) is upgraded to Outperform from Market Perform with a $120 price target, up from $72, at FBR Capital to reflect what it sees as an upcoming significant step-up in efficiency of capital deployment as well as enhanced Wolfcamp potential in the Permian Basin.
    • The firm believes that as the Wolfcamp program gets de-risked, capital deployed in the play could go to ~$550M in 2015 and $1B in 2017 from $175M in 2013.
    • Because of the efficiency of capital from increasing lateral length and stages, the firm expects returns in the area on capital deployed to go from 45% pretax IRR to 95% pretax IRR by 2015 and 117% in 2017.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:10 AM
  • TATT

    TAT Technologies dips on lower Y/Y Q2 revenues

    • T.A.T. Technologies (TATT -2.3%) slips after reporting Q2 revenue that declined on a Y/Y basis.
    • Q2 net income came in at $1M, or $0.12 per share, on revenues of $21.9M. In the same period last year, the company reported a net loss of $4.2M, or $0.48 per share, on revenues of $22.1M.
    • The company attributes the lower revenues to a continued decline in sales in its OEM of Heat Management and Electric Motion Systems operating segments.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:08 AM
  • LDK

    LDK Solar dives on worries about debt, cash burn; peers also lower

    • Citing insufficient cash, LDK (LDK -8%) says it will delay a semi-annual debt coupon payment due tomorrow.
    • LDK's cash/bank deposit balance fell to $285.4M at the end of Q2 from $342.5M at the end of Q1. Meanwhile, its debt balance was north of $2.65B at the end of Q2.
    • Raymond James' Pavel Molchanov: "LDK's balance sheet makes it a 'zombie company.' It only survives due to continued bailouts from local or provincial authorities." The Suntech saga suggests Chinese authorities aren't as quick to embrace solar bailouts as they once were.
    • While many Chinese solar names are now reporting fairly healthy gross margins, LDK's remain bleak. Q2 GM was -46.9% vs. -57% in Q1 and -39.1% a year earlier.
    • LDK's balance sheet and cash issues are a big reason it has largely missed out on this year's giant solar stock rally. Nonetheless, the company and its peers are heading in the same direction (TAN -4.3%) today. YGE -6.9%. CSIQ -5.8%. SPWR -4.9%. CSUN -4.5%. SCTY -4.3%. TSL -4.2%. SUNE -5.7%. FSLR -3.2%.
    • JA Solar (JASO -4.8%) is also among the decliners, even though it has announced a deal to develop 300MW worth of Chinese solar plants.
    • LDK's Q2 results: I, II
     
     
     
     
    | 11:06 AM
  • GT

    Goodyear Tire on the move after labor deal

    • Shares of Goodyear Tire (GT +1.8%) move higher after the company reports forward progress with its new contract with the United Steelworkers union.
    • The company will be able to freeze defined-benefit pension plans under the new deal.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:53 AM
  • UAL

    Ugly day for airline stocks

    • A surge in oil prices following renewed tension in Syria is wreaking havoc with airline stocks.
    • The sector had just gotten itself on firmer footing following the turbulence over the DOJ's suit to block the U.S. Airways-American Airlines merger before the Middle East issues escalated.
    • Decliners: UAL -5.9%, DAL -5.5%, ALK -4.4%, RJET -4.2%, LCC -3.1%, LUV -2.6%, SAVE -2.4%, JBLU -1.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:36 AM
  • URALL

    Russia-Belarus potash dispute sparks diplomatic row

    • Potash companies slide as yesterday's arrest in Belarus of the head of Russian potash company Uralkali (OTC:URALL) threatens to turn into a major diplomatic row.
    • The recriminations, and a threat by Belarus to hold CEOÂ Vladislav Baumgertner for at least two months, suggest there is little hope of an early reconciliation in the potash dispute that has already lowered prices.
    • The break-up of Belarusian Potash could have serious consequences for Belarus, where potash made up more than 7% of exports last year.
    • POT -1.1%, MOS -1.8%, AGU -0.4%, IPI -1.6%, SQM -0.8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:34 AM | 5 Comments
  • QIHU

    A roundup of tech analyst ratings changes

    • Qihoo (QIHU +3.1%) has been upgraded to Buy by BNP Paribas and Jefferies a day after the company posted a Q2 beat and strong Q3 guidance.
    • Blackbaud (BLKB +5.3%) has been upgraded to Buy by Stifel following its CEO transition news.
    • Peregrine Semi (PSMI +1.6%) has been started at Outperform by JMP.
    • Synnex (SNX -4%) has been cut to Underperform by Raymond James.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:52 AM

  • Southeast Asian markets, Turkish shares plunge amid laundry list of worries

    • It's another abysmal day for Southeast Asian markets as Syria jitters exacerbate an already delicate situation. Emerging markets are facing pressure from slowing growth, currency woes in Indonesia, India, Brazil, and Turkey, and a looming Fed taper.
    • Indonesian (IDX, EIDO), Thai (THD), and Philippine (EPHE) shares tumble 3.7%, 2.7%, and 4% respectively and are all in bear market territory after plunging more than 20% from highs hit in May.
    • Performing only marginally better are stocks in Malaysia (EWM), Vietnam (VNM), and Singapore (EWS, EWSS) where shares are off 1.2%, 1%, and 1.6% respectively.
    • Turkish stocks (TUR) are off 3.3% and have fallen ~41% since May 22.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:25 AM

  • Market preview

    • U.S. stock futures and European shares are solidly lower, while most Asian equities also fell, on the increasing prospects that the U.S. will take military action against Syria after John Kerry accused the Assad regime of using chemical weapons on its citizens.
    • The news that the U.S. will hit its debt ceiling is also hurting the mood.
    • The S&P Mini is -1%, and some emerging-market currencies are also taking a beating, although oil is +2.5% and gold +1.7%.
    • JCPenney is -2% after Bill Ackman sells his 18% holding in the retailer.
    • Later: Consumer Confidence, State Street Investor Confidence Index, Richmond Fed Mfg.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:20 AM
  • UNXL

    UniPixel +5.3% premarket on bullish Cowen note

    • Cowen, which is reiterating an Outperform and $46 PT (over 2.5x UniPixel's (NASDAQ:UNXL) current price), says talks with touch sensor manufacturing partner Kodak lead it to believe the company is on track to produce 1M sensors/month by year's end.
    • More from Cowen: "Kodak is investing significant capital and staff, and contributing technology expertise and enhancements."
    • UniPixel shares jumped after the company announced a deal with Kodak in April, through which the companies promised to invest $24M in 2013 in creating a 100K sq. foot manufacturing/testing facility. Kodak's restructuring plan was approved by a court last week.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:16 AM | 11 Comments
  • URZ

    Uranerz Energy in 8.55M-share bought deal financing arrangement

    • Uranerz Energy (NYSEMKT:URZ) -11.1% premarket after entering into a bought deal financing arrangement to sell 8.55M common shares at $1.17/share.
    • Expected gross proceeds are ~$10M.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:12 AM

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: CPRX +62%. CCCR-OLD +20%. VRNG +8%. ANV +7%. MNKD +6%.
    • Losers: OTC:ACUR -25%. URZ -11%. LDK -10%. HDB -9%. TSL -6%. TLK -6%. IBN -6%. ING -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:08 AM
  • MNKD

    MannKind addresses critics with FAQ list

    • Shares of MannKind (NASDAQ:MNKD) rise 4.3% premarket apparently in response to an SEC filing (8-K) which announces the publication of a series of FAQs (regarding the Affinity trial results) and responses from the company.
    • MNKD addresses the perceived discrepancy between the 0.4% change in HbA1c observed in Affinity 2 and the 0.5% change the original study design appeared to have called for the demonstrate superiority. There's nothing new here. The company says the 0.5% figure was related to the design of the trial and that the results were "extremely significant" — that's the same thing they said on the conference call.
    • Also addressed is Summer Street's now infamous "unprecedented" comment regarding data on the MedTone inhaler. MNKD says the performance of MedTone and the Gen2 device is "comparable" and, without mentioning any names, calls Summer Street's analysis "alarmist" and "subjective."
    • Investors can read the full FAQ list here.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:55 AM | 8 Comments

  • CPRX

    Catalyst's Firdapse drug gets breakthrough status

    • Catalyst Pharmaceutical (CPRX +47.2%) has received breakthrough therapy designation from the FDA for its Firdapse drug for treating Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS), a rare autoimmune disease that can be severely disabling and even life-threatening.
    • "With no approved or effective symptomatic treatment currently available for LEMS, Firdapse has the potential to be the first-line treatment option for patients with this rare condition," says Catalyst CEO Patrick McEnany.
    • The primary symptom of LEMS is muscle weakness, which makes walking difficult. Sufferers can also experience problems with swallowing and talking, the drooping of eyelids and facial weakness. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 8:22 AM

  • European shares lower on Syrian tension

    • As in Asia, shares in Europe are lower over the increasing tensions with Syria following what appears to be its use of chemical weapons.
    • "The apparent certainty that military action against Syria is on its way has traders highly uncertain about what the repercussions will be for igniting a powder keg in such an already volatile region," writes Capital Spreads trader Jonathan Sudaria.
    • The U.S. Treasury's confirmation that the government will hit the debt ceiling in mid-October is also weighing on sentiment.
    • A continuing improvement in German business confidence doesn't seem to be having any effect at all.

  • Wariness over possible U.S. action on Syria hits Asian stocks

    • Asian shares are mostly lower after John Kerry signaled that the U.S. could take military action against Syria due to strong suspicions that the latter used chemical weapons against its citizens.
    • The Turkish lira hits a record low of 2.0163 to the dollar, although the yen is up, with the USD-JPY -0.7% at 97.85.
    • "It's a risk-off story because of Syria and also if you see broad repatriation from emerging-markets currencies, the yen will benefit," says Michael Turner, a strategist at RBC.
    • However, Chinese shares are higher following positive data for industrial profits.
    • Japan -0.7%, Hong Kong -0.5%, China +0.3%, India -2.8%, Turkey (TUR) -2.9%.

  • Rupee dives to more fresh lows after food bill passed

    • India's rupee has dropped to more record lows against the dollar and shares have plunged after the country's Lower House of Parliament approved a $20B plan to provide cheap grain for the poor, or almost 70% of the country's 1.2B people.
    • The bill has prompted concerns that it will add to India's fiscal deficit.
    • The USD-INR is +2.3% to 65.805 after earlier hitting 65.93. The currency has plummeted this year for a variety of reasons, including the lack of economic reform and the the Fed's intention to start tapering its QE program.
    • The Sensex is -2.3%.
